bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1947

div1.p: Hench is unable to resolve the discrepancy concerning the number of yellow fever huts. He discusses Siler's health. Lazear's daughter has her father's missing microscope.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Albert E. Truby, February 20, 1947
div1.opener:
February 20, 1947
General Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
My dear General Truby:
div1.p:
Thank you so very much for your letters of January 29th.
I shall file the one to Mr. Hoeber and not use it now. I hope
you are not working too hard on my series of questionnaires. I
have just had another letter from Lambert and I am sending you a
copy. I simply cannot understand how he could live for several
months at the yellow fever hospital and be incorrect when he says
that there were only four little buildings when the maps and the
history of the hospital, et cetera speak of eight. That is a
difficult contradiction to unravel.

General Kean just returned a copy of my interview with
the Reeds. He agreed with me that it was interesting but there
wasn't much new information therein. Colonel Siler has been seri-
ously ill. He had a prostatectomy but it was not malignant. He
developed a severe postoperative pneumonia I believe and was
critically ill in the Walter Reed Hospital but has improved re-
markably in the last month. Thank you very much for Colonel La
Garde's full name. I just heard from Peggy Lazear Briggs. The
missing microscope of Doctor Lazear is found. She has it!
My very best wishes to you all.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alp
